anchor.surface_text: Upon an application under section 66 1  of the Act the tribunal stated a case to the High Court referring the two. questions

issues.text: On the facts and in the circumstances of this case is the surplus of Rs. 13,05,144 arising out of the sale of the plant and machinery of the sugar factory chargeable under section 10 (2) (vii)?

anchor.surface_text: On the facts and in the circumstances of this case is the surplus of Rs. 13,05,144 arising out of the sale of the plant and machinery of the sugar factory chargeable under section 10  2   vii

issues.text: Was the profit of Rs. 15,882 on the sale of stores of the factory taxable under the Income-tax Act in the circumstances of this case?

anchor.surface_text: Was the profit of Rs. 15,882 on the sale of stores of the factory taxable under the Income-tax Act in the circumstances of this case ?

issues.text: Whether tax is payable under section 10(1) only in respect of the profits or gains of any business, profession or vocation carried on by the assessee?

anchor.surface_text: The relevant portion of section 10 of the Income-tax Act as amended by Act VI of 1939was as follows -- 10  1  The tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head Profits and gains of business, profession or vocation in respect of the profits or gains of any business, profession or vocation carried on by him.

issues.text: Whether the machinery or plant must have been used for the purposes of the business during the accounting year to attract the operation of the second proviso to section 10(2)(vii)?

anchor.surface_text: Business is defined by section 2, sub-section  4  as including any trade, companymerce or manufacture, or any adventure or companycern in the nature of trade, companymerce or manufacture. As pointed out by the Judicial Committee in Shaw Wallace Co.s case 1  the fundamental idea underlying each of these words is the companytinuous

issues.text: Whether 'carried on' in section 10(1) connotes the continuous exercise of an activity?

anchor.surface_text: as pointed out by the Judicial Committee in Shaw Wallace Co.s case 1  the fundamental idea underlying each of these words is the companytinuous exercise of an activity and the same central idea is implicit in the words carried on by him occurring in section 10  1

issues.text: Whether the High Court can review the Tribunal's findings of fact if the Tribunal misunderstood the statutory language or the finding is unsupported by evidence?

anchor.surface_text: Although the High Court will number disturb or go behind the finding of fact of the tribunal, it is number well settled that where it is companypetent for a tribunal to make findings in fact which are excluded from review, the appeal companyrt has always jurisdiction to intervene if it appears either that the tribunal has misunderstood the statutory language--because the proper companystruction of the statutory language is a matter of law--or that the tribunal has made a finding for which there is numberevidence

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal misdirected itself in holding that the sale of machinery was part of carrying on business and that the second proviso to section 10(2)(vii) applied?

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the tribunal misdirected itself in law as to the meaning and import of the relevant provisions of section 10 of the Act. t companypletely overlooked the fact which is plainly in evidence on the record that the machinery and plant which were sold had number at all been used for the purposes of the business carried on in the accounting year and companysequently the second proviso to section 10  2   vii  companyld have numberapplication to the sale proceeds of such machinery and plant.

If... number at all been used... proviso does number companye into operation.

arguments.claim: Activities during year were realisation of assets on impending liquidation, not carrying on business

anchor.surface_text: Amongst other things, the Income tax Officer wanted to know the liquidators objection why the companypanys activities during the previous year might number be treated as amounting to a realisation of assets on impending liquidation rather than to the carrying on of business within the meaning of the Income-tax Act.

holdings.text: The tax is payable only in respect of the profits or gains of the business which is carried on by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it is clear that the tax is payable only in respect of the profits or gains of the business which is carried on by the assessee. Sub-section (2) permits allowances to be made before the taxable profits are ascertained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets s.10(1) requiring continuous exercise of activity, following Judicial Committee in Shaw Wallace & Co.

holdings.text: The second proviso to section 10(2)(vii) applies only to machinery or plant used for the purposes of the business during the accounting year.

anchor.surface_text: Any such machinery or plant in the proviso clearly refers to the machinery or plant... used for the purposes of the business... the machinery or plant must be such as were used... at least for a part of the accounting year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation linking proviso to main clause allowances for used assets; scheme of sub-s.(2) requires prior use.

holdings.text: The surplus of Rs. 13,05,144 arising out of the sale of the plant and machinery is not chargeable under section 10(2)(vii).

anchor.surface_text: the tribunal misdirected itself in law... the machinery and plant which were sold had not at all been used for the purposes of the business carried on in the accounting year and consequently the second proviso to section 10(2)(vii) could have no application

holdings.reasoning_summary: Machinery not used at all during accounting year (facts f20,f21,f29); proviso inapplicable as per textual reading.

holdings.text: The Tribunal misdirected itself in law by misunderstanding the statutory language of section 10 and overlooking non-use of machinery.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the tribunal misdirected itself in law as to the meaning and import of the relevant provisions of section 10 of the Act. It completely overlooked the fact... that the machinery and plant... had not at all been used

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal ignored plain evidence of non-use and misapplied proviso; findings vitiated by legal error.

holdings.text: Appellate court may intervene in Tribunal's findings of fact if Tribunal misunderstood statutory language or finding unsupported by evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Although the High Court will not disturb or go behind the finding of fact of the tribunal, it is now well settled that... the appeal court has always jurisdiction to intervene if it appears either that the tribunal has misunderstood the statutory language... or that the tribunal has made a finding for which there is no evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Fraser; proper construction of statute is question of law.

holdings.text: Tribunal's findings that company carried on business up to and after sale are inconclusive for applicability of s.10(2)(vii).

anchor.surface_text: this finding that the company carried on its business up to the 7th December, 1943, certainly does not indicate that the company was also carrying on any business of growing sugarcane or manufacturing sugar by the use of the machinery or plant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admission consistent with selling sugar stock only; no manufacturing; post-sale business unrelated to machinery.

holdings.text: Tribunal's reasoning internally inconsistent: if sale part of business, taxable under s.10(1) without proviso; if under proviso, not part of business.

anchor.surface_text: If, as held by the tribunal, the sale of the machinery was a part of... carrying on of the business then... assessable under... section 10(1) and it would not be necessary to have recourse to the statutory fiction... If the profits... are to be made assessable under the second proviso... then it must be conceded that these deemed profits were not in reality the profits

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical inconsistency vitiates decision; harmonious construction requires choosing one path.

holdings.text: No opinion necessary on whether 'used' includes passive user.

anchor.surface_text: The word used has been read in some of the pool cases in a wide sense so as to include a passive as well as active user. It is not necessary, for the purposes of the present appeal, to express any opinion on that point

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary for decision as no use at all; High Courts differ.
